'''Extended female sexuality''' is where the female of a [[species]] mate despite being infertile.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> In most species, the female only engages in [[Sexual intercourse|copulation]] when she is [[Fertility|fertile]]. However, extended sexuality has been documented in [[Primate|old world primates]], [[Bird|pair bonded birds]] and some [[insects]]<ref name="evolution of mind" /> (such as [[carrion beetles]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pellissier|first1=S.M.|title=The ecology and behaviour of burying beetles|journal=Annual Review of Entomology|date=1998|volume=43|issue=1|pages=595â618|doi=10.1146/annurev.ento.43.1.595}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Muller|first1=J. K.|last2=Eggert|first2=A. K.|title=Paternity assurance by helpful males: Adaptations to sperm competition in burying beetles|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|date=1989|volume=24|issue=4|pages=245â249}}</ref>). Extended sexuality is most prominent in human females who exhibit no change in copulation rate across the [[Menstrual cycle|ovarian cycle]].<ref name="human oestrus" /> Although this behaviour incurs costs to females, such as energy and time,<ref name="evolution of mind" /> many researchers have proposed reasons for its existence. These hypotheses include the male assistance hypothesis, which proposes that females gain non-genetic benefits (such as food and shelter) in exchange for sexual access.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> A sub-hypothesis of this is [[Sarah Blaffer Hrdy|Hrdy]]'s, proposing extended female sexuality as an [[Adaptation|adaptive]] process aiming to creating [[Father|paternity]] confusion in males.<ref name=":0">{{cite book|last1=Hrdy|first1=S. B.|title=The woman that never evolved|date=1999|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, Mass.|isbn=9780674955394|edition=With a new prerface and bibliographical updates.}}</ref><ref name="Pearson Education">{{cite book|last1=Buss|first1=D. M.|title=Evolutionary psychology : the new science of the mind.|date=2011|publisher=Pearson Education|location=[S.l.]|isbn=978-0205002788|edition=4th ed., International}}</ref> Alternative hypotheses, classified as 'male-driven', claim that extended female sexuality occurs due to male adaptations, resulting from an inability to detect fertility status in females or to dampen immune responses against sperm.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Fedorka|first=Kenneth M.|last2=Zuk|first2=Marlene|date=2005-11-01|title=Sexual conflict and female immune suppression in the cricket, Allonemobious socius|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1420-9101.2005.00942.x/abstract|journal=Journal of Evolutionary Biology|language=en|volume=18|issue=6|pages=1515â1522|doi=10.1111/j.1420-9101.2005.00942.x|pmid=16313464|issn=1420-9101}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{cite book|last1=Pitnick|first1=S.|last2=Hosken|first2=D.|last3=Birkhead|first3=T.|title=Sperm biology an evolutionary perspective|date=2009|publisher=Elsevier/Academic Press|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9780080919874|edition=1.}}</ref> Finally, Spuhler's hypothesis suggests that the behaviour may have arisen as an incidental effect of larger adrenal glands in humans.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" />
[[File:SDM-circle3.svg|thumb|The image shows the menstrual cycle for a human (starting from day one of the cycle, and ending at the last day of the cycle). Author:Vargklo]]
==Occurrence==
===In non-humans=== Although not found in all organisms, researchers have identified sexual intercourse patterns in certain animals that reflect extended female sexuality, such as in some old world primates, birds and insects.<ref name="evolution of mind" /> Extensive research has focused on analysing the [[White-toothed shrew|musk shrew]]'s rate of sexual behaviour.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rissman|first1=E. F.|title=Social variables influence female sexual behavior in the musk shrew (Suncus murinus)|journal=Journal of Comparative Psychology|date=1987|volume=101|issue=1|pages=3â6|doi=10.1037/0735-7036.101.1.3|pmid=3568606}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rissman|first1=E. F.|title=Evidence that Neural Aromatization of Androgen Regulates the Expression of Sexual Behaviour in Female Musk Shrews|journal=Journal of Neuroendocrinology|date=August 1991|volume=3|issue=4|pages=441â448|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2826.1991.tb00301.x|pmid=19215490}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rissman|first1=E. F.|last2=Crews|first2=D.|title=Hormonal correlates of sexual behavior in the female musk shrew: The role of estradiol|journal=Physiology & Behavior|date=January 1988|volume=44|issue=1|pages=1â7|doi=10.1016/0031-9384(88)90338-1}}</ref> The only period that is associated with a drop in female [[receptivity]] to copulation is during mid to late [[pregnancy]]; yet, even at this time, occasional mating is reported. Therefore, researchers have concluded that this animal has similar sexual receptivity across infertile and fertile phases.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Freeman|first1=L. M.|last2=Rissman|first2=E. F.|title=Neural aromatization and the control of sexual behavior|journal=Trends in Endocrinology & Metabolism|date=November 1996|volume=7|issue=9|pages=334â338|doi=10.1016/S1043-2760(96)00156-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rissman|first1=E. F.|last2=Silveira|first2=J.|last3=Bronson|first3=F.H|title=Patterns of sexual receptivity in the female musk shrew (Suncus murinus)|journal=Hormones and Behavior|date=June 1988|volume=22|issue=2|pages=186â193|doi=10.1016/0018-506X(88)90065-7|pmid=3397051}}</ref> Within primates, research has consistently found evidence of extended female sexuality in the [[Rhesus macaque|rhesus monkey]] and [[chimpanzee]]s. Both of these primates mate at all stages of the ovarian cycle, with only slight increases in sexual receptivity during [[fertility|fertile stages]], and decreases during [[menstruation]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The EncyclopÃ¦dia of Sexual Behaviour, Volume 1|author1=Albert Ellis |author2=Albert Abarbanel |publisher=Elsevier|year=2013|isbn=1483225100|location=London|pages=140}}</ref>
===In humans=== Human females are considered to exhibit the greatest degree of extended female sexuality, with receptivity to sexual intercourse remaining constant across fertile and infertile phases of the reproductive cycle, including during [[pregnancy]], [[lactation]], and in adolescence. In a study of 20,000 women from 13 countries, frequency of copulation was reportedly the same across all stages of the ovarian cycle. The only notable drop in sexual behaviour occurred during [[menstruation]]. Therefore, women largely showed the same level of sexual behaviour in the non-fertile phases of their ovarian cycles as in the fertile phases.<ref name="human oestrus" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brewis|first1=A.|last2=Meyer|first2=M.|title=Demographic evidence that human ovulation is undetectable (at least in pair bonds)|journal=Current Anthropology|date=2005|volume=46|issue=3|pages=465â471|doi=10.1086/430016}}</ref>
Researchers have investigated the effect of [[Hormonal contraception|hormonal contraceptive]] use in women on the frequency of sexual intercourse.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Guida|first1=M.|title=Effects of two types of hormonal contraception--oral versus intravaginal--on the sexual life of women and their partners|journal=Human Reproduction|date=17 December 2004|volume=20|issue=4|pages=1100â1106|doi=10.1093/humrep/deh686|pmid=15608030}}</ref> Many of these contraceptives mimic a pregnancy state in females by altering hormone levels. Therefore, women who use these contraceptives do not experience the fertile phases of their cycles. In a systematic review, it appeared that the frequency of sexual intercourse was unaffected by contraceptive use in the majority of women. Although artificially created, this adds to the literature documenting the existence of copulation in humans during non-fertile periods.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burrows|first1=L. J.|last2=Basha|first2=M.|last3=Goldstein|first3=A. T.|title=The Effects of Hormonal Contraceptives on Female Sexuality: A Review|journal=The Journal of Sexual Medicine|date=September 2012|volume=9|issue=9|pages=2213â2223|doi=10.1111/j.1743-6109.2012.02848.x|pmid=22788250}}</ref>
=== Impact of concealed ovulation === In order to encourage [[mating]] in non-conceptive periods and to encourage males to maintain their proximity, males must possess imperfect knowledge of the female's [[fertility]] status. This is achieved through [[concealed ovulation]] in most animals that exhibit extended female sexuality.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal|last1=Grebe|first1=N. M.|last2=Gangestad|first2=S. W.|last3=Garver-Apgar|first3=C. E.|last4=Thornhill|first4=R.|title=Women's luteal-phase sexual proceptivity and the functions of extended sexuality|journal=Psychological Science|date=2013|volume=24|issue=10|pages=2106â2110|pmid=23965377|doi=10.1177/0956797613485965}}</ref> A review of studies revealed that, in humans, females only exhibit subtle changes during [[estrus cycle|estrus]], making it difficult for males to assess fertility with precision.<ref name="G&H (2015)">{{cite journal|last1=Gangestad|first1=S. W.|last2=Haselton|first2=M. G.|title=Human estrus: implications for relationship science.|journal=Current Opinion in Psychology|date=2015|volume=1|pages=45â51|doi=10.1016/j.copsyc.2014.12.007}}</ref> In the [[!Kung people|!Kung tribe]], for instance, females lack any overt signals of fertility and are continuously [[sexually receptive|receptive]] to sexual intercourse, encouraging males to remain and provide resources.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gould|first1=J. L.|last2=Gould|first2=C. G.|title=Sexual Selection: Mate Choice and Courtship in Nature.|date=1989|publisher=Scientific American Library|location=New York|page=253}}</ref>
[[File:BronisÅaw Malinowski among Trobriand tribe.jpg|thumb|The image shows the Trobriand tribe with [[BronisÅaw Malinowski]]. Author:Unknown]]
==Explanations==
=== Male assistance hypothesis === Mating outside the fertile window of their [[menstrual cycle|ovarian cycle]] may incur considerable costs for females, such as in time and energy usage. To counteract these costs, the male assistance hypothesis argues that females exhibit extended sexuality to obtain resources from males.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=FÃ¼rtbauer|first1=I.|last2=Heistermann|first2=M.|last3=SchÃ¼lke|first3=O.|last4=Ostner|first4=J.|title=Concealed fertility and extended female sexuality in a non-human primate (Macaca assamensis)|journal=PLOS ONE|date=2011|volume=6|issue=8|pages=e23105|bibcode=2011PLoSO...623105F|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0023105|pmid=21853074|pmc=3154278}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Higham|first1=J. P.|last2=Heistermann|first2=M.|last3=Saggau|first3=C.|last4=Agil|first4=M.|last5=Perwitasari-Farajallah|first5=D.|last6=Engelhardt|first6=A.|title=Sexual signalling in female crested macaques and the evolution of primate fertility signals.|journal=BMC Evolutionary Biology|date=2012|volume=12|issue=1|page=89|doi=10.1186/1471-2148-12-89|pmid=22708622|pmc=3483276}}</ref> These resources vary between species, but can include food, social alliance, and protection of the female and her offspring.<ref name="evolution of mind">{{cite book|last1=Gangestad|first1=S.W.|last2=Simpson|first2=J. A.|title=The evolution of mind: Fundamental questions and controversies.|date=2007|publisher=Guilford Press|pages=391â397}}</ref> For example, in the [[Trobriand Islands|Trobriand]] tribe, men give women gifts in exchange for sexual access.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilson|first1=Margo|last2=Daly|first2=Martin|title=Sex, evolution, and behavior|date=1983|publisher=Wadsworth Pub. Co.|location=Belmont, Calif.|isbn=978-0871507679|edition=2nd}}</ref> From this hypothesis, '''three predictions''' can be made.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad">{{cite book|last1=Thornhill|first1=R.|last2=Gangestad|first2=S.W.|title=The evolutionary biology of human female sexuality|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press}}</ref>
====Male provision of non-genetic resources==== Firstly, in species that demonstrate extended female sexuality, there should be evidence that the males provide non-genetic resources to females. This prediction is supported in a variety of animals,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=RodrÄ±Ìguez-GironÃ©s|first1=M. A.|last2=Enquist|first2=M.|title=The evolution of female sexuality|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=2001|volume=61|issue=4|pages=695â704|doi=10.1006/anbe.2000.1630}}</ref> with reviews revealing that male assistance (such as food or protection), is provided to certain [[mammal]]s and communally breeding birds in exchange for mating outside the conceptive period.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stacey|first1=P. B.|title=Female promiscuity and male reproductive success in social birds and mammals.|journal=American Naturalist|date=1982|pages=51â64|doi=10.1086/283969}}</ref> For example, female [[Common blackbird|blackbirds]] that solicit mating outside the fertile period have increased [[Mating|mate guarding]] from their pair-bonded partner. This increases protection against other [[Sexual coercion|sexually coercive]] males and ensures the provision of other material benefits.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wysocki|first=Dariusz|last2=Halupka|first2=Konrad|date=2004-04-01|title=The Frequency and Timing of Courtship and Copulation in Blackbirds, Turdus Merula, Reflect Sperm Competition and Sexual Conflict|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/10.1163/156853904323066766|journal=Behaviour|volume=141|issue=4|pages=501â512|doi=10.1163/156853904323066766|issn=1568-539X}}</ref> In a review investigating primates that exhibit extended female sexuality, it was noted that females engaging in extended sexuality benefited from increased offspring protection and paternal care from males.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soltis|first=Joseph|date=2002-01-01|title=Do primate females gain nonprocreative benefits by mating with multiple males? Theoretical and empirical considerations|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/evan.10025/abstract|journal=Evolutionary Anthropology |volume=11|issue=5|pages=187â197|doi=10.1002/evan.10025|issn=1520-6505}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Slater|first1=P. J. B.|last2=Rosenblatt|first2=J. S.|last3=Snowdon|first3=C. T.|last4=Roper|first4=T. J.|last5=Naquib|first5=M.|title=Advances in the study of behavior.|date=2003|publisher=Elsevier/Academic Press|location=San Diego, Calif.|isbn=9780080490144}}</ref>
====Enhanced reproductive success==== Secondly, in order to outweigh the aforementioned costs, [[mating]] during infertile phases should increase females' [[reproductive success]] by increasing the number of offspring produced. Current research has only investigated this factor indirectly, and it has predominantly been investigated in insects. For example, when male insects deliver material benefits in exchange for sexual access, the reproductive success of the females increases with the number of matings.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Arnqvist|first1=G.|last2=Nilsson|first2=T.|title=The evolution of polyandry: multiple mating and female fitness in insects|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=2000|volume=60|issue=2|pages=145â164|pmid=10973716|doi=10.1006/anbe.2000.1446}}</ref> It is important to note that the [[mating]] behaviour assessed was not limited to extended female sexuality. Hence, it only provides indirect support for the second prediction.
====Shifting mate preferences and behaviour across the ovarian cycle==== {{See also|Ovulatory shift hypothesis}}
The final prediction of the male-assistance hypothesis has been extensively investigated. It predicts that females will exhibit differing [[mating preferences|mate preferences]] during fertile and non-fertile periods. Specifically, when fertile, the females will be sensitive to indicators of high genetic quality to increase the genetic quality of her [[offspring]].<ref name="human oestrus" /> Conversely, outside of the fertile period, females will show a preference for males who can provide resources for her and her offspring. In most species, males of higher genetic quality offer fewer non-genetic resources (such as shelter and food) than those of lower quality, so females are likely to choose different males at each stage.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" />
Evidence for this prediction has been found in many different species. In [[Chicken|hens]], those near peak fertility show a preference for socially dominant roosters with large [[Comb (anatomy)|combs]]. Larger combs have been reliably associated with health and [[offspring]] survival so reliably indicate the genetic quality of the [[rooster]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Parker|first1=T. H.|last2=Ligon|first2=J. D.|title=Female mating preferences in red junglefowl: a meta-analysis.|journal=Ethology, Ecology & Evolution|date=2003|volume=15|issue=1|pages=63â72|doi=10.1080/08927014.2003.9522691}}</ref> In the non-fertile phases, hens mate more indiscriminately with less regard for the larger comb size. A similar pattern emerges in humans. A review of relevant studies on female preferences across the [[menstrual cycle|ovarian cycle]] reveals that women show a greater preference for [[masculinity|masculine]] traits in fertile phases, especially for [[human mating strategies|short term mating]] intention. This finding occurs across a variety of traits, such as masculine [[human voice|voices]], body and facial features, [[odor|scent]], and [[Display (zoology)#Among humans|behavioural displays]].<ref name="human oestrus">{{cite journal|last1=Gangestad|first1=S. W.|last2=Thornhill|first2=R.|title=Human oestrus|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|date=2008|volume=275|issue=1638|pages=991â1000|doi=10.1098/rspb.2007.1425|pmc=2394562}}</ref> The level of masculinity acts as an indicator of genetic quality through its association with high [[testosterone]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Penton-Voak|first1=I. S.|last2=Perrett|first2=D. I.|last3=Castles|first3=D. L.|last4=Kobayashi|first4=T.|last5=Burt|first5=D. M.|last6=Murray|first6=L. K.|last7=Minamisawa|first7=R.|title=Menstrual cycle alters face preference|journal=Nature|date=1999|volume=399|issue=6738|pages=741â742|bibcode=1999Natur.399..741P|doi=10.1038/21557|pmid=10391238}}</ref> Similarly, women show a preference for higher levels of [[symmetry in biology|symmetry]], which is thought to indicate underlying developmental stability.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 9375532 | volume=72 | title=Developmental stability, disease and medicine | journal=Biol Rev Camb Philos Soc | pages=497â548 | last1 = Thornhill | first1 = R | last2 = MÃ¸ller | first2 = AP | doi=10.1017/s0006323197005082}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gildersleeve|first1=K.|last2=Haselton|first2=M. G.|last3=Fales|first3=M. R.|title=Do women's mate preferences change across the ovulatory cycle? A meta-analytic review.|journal=Psychological Bulletin|date=2014|volume=140|issue=5|pages=1205â1259|doi=10.1037/a0035438|pmid=24564172}}</ref> However, during infertile phases, women prefer males with lower masculinity and symmetry, as they tend to be more willing to offer material benefits.<ref name="evolution of mind" />
[[File:Big red rooster.jpg|thumb|The image shows a rooster with a comb. The comb concerns the red bit of 'skin' underneath the beak. Author: BazzaDaRambler]]
In addition to impacting [[mating preferences]], females have been found to exhibit differing mating behaviour at different cycle stages. An analysis of 121 studies with female birds showed that most mate outside their [[pair bond]] at a higher rate when fertile, especially when the primary partner possesses indicators of low quality [[gene]]s. During infertile phases, birds showed reductions in this behaviour, suggesting that the function of extended female sexuality is not to increase the genetic quality of offspring.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=AkÃ§ay|first1=E.|last2=Roughgarden|first2=J.|title=Extra-pair paternity in birds: review of the genetic benefits.|journal=Evolutionary Ecology Research|date=2007|volume=9|issue=5|page=855}}</ref> In humans, females show increased motivation for mating with other males at [[menstrual cycle|mid-cycle]] without an accompanying increase in [[sexual intercourse|copulation]] with their long term partner, especially if the partner was less physically attractive.<ref name="human oestrus"/>
===Hrdy's hypothesis===
[[File:Baby ginger monkey.jpg|thumb|An infant lutung (old world primate). Source: flickr.com]] Hrdy's hypothesis is an extension of the male assistance hypothesis, in that both hypotheses argue that women have evolved this adaptation to gain some tangible benefit from males. According to Hrdy's hypothesis,<ref name=":0"/><ref name="Pearson Education"/> extended female sexuality is an [[Adaptation|adaptive]] process with an aim of creating paternity confusion in their male counterparts.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> Paternity confusion refers to the male being unsure as to whether [[offspring]] are genetically his own. If the female mates with different males (at all points of her [[Menstrual cycle|ovarian cycle]]) whilst concealing [[fertility]], then the males will inevitably have paternity confusion.
Paternity confusion is proposed to be an adaptive function for preventing [[Infanticide (zoology)|infanticide]].<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Significance of Male and Female Reproductive Strategies for Male Reproductive Success in Wild Longtailed Macaques (Macaca Fascicularis)|last = Engelhardt|first = Antje|publisher = Cuvillier Verlag|year = 2004|isbn = |location = GÃ¶ttingen|pages = 3}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Infanticide by Males and Its Implications|last = Van Schaik|first = Carl|publisher = Cambridge University Press|year = 2000|isbn = |location = Cambridge|pages = 361}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Primates and Cetaceans: Field Research and Conservation of Complex Mammalian Societies|last = Yamagiwa|first = Juichi|publisher = Springer Science & Business Media|year = 2013|isbn = |location = Tokyo|pages = 387}}</ref> Thus, if the female can successfully create paternity confusion, males will be less likely to kill her offspring, as the lack of paternity certainty means that they run the risk of killing their own genetic [[offspring]]. Additionally, the males, in turn, are likely to protect the same female's offspring from infanticide that may be committed by other adults within the species. Once again, this is because they are uncertain about paternity, and aim to protect infants that are genetically their own.
====Paternity confusion in primates==== Researchers have analysed the behaviour of [[chimpanzee]]s, with particular reference to [[Female copulatory vocalizations|copulation calling]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Townsend|first=Simon|date=2008|title=Female chimpanzees use copulation calls flexibly to prevent social competition|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0002431|journal=PLOS ONE |volume=3 |issue= 6|pages= e2431.|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0002431|pmid=22423311|pmc=3278306|access-date=|bibcode=2008PLoSO...3.2431T}}</ref> Copulation calling is a type of vocalisation used to attract mates. The calls are vocalised either before, during, or after sexual intercourse. Copulation calling, in line with Hrdy's hypothesis, may then be one way to ensure that the female can mate with as many different males as possible, causing paternity confusion. Indeed, the authors found that the probability of copulatory calling in female chimpanzees was not modulated by the ovarian phase of the female caller, thereby aiding paternity confusion. This paternity confusion ultimately ensures that the woman has access to the resources of a number of different males. These resources can be utilised by her, as well as by her offspring.
Criticism of Hrdy's hypothesis emerges from evidence which suggests that male primates can discriminate between their own offspring and the offspring of others.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Biosocial Foundations of Family Processes|last = Booth|first = Alan|publisher = Springer Science & Business Media|year = 2010|isbn = |location = New York|pages = 36}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Buchan|first=J. C.|date=2003|title=True paternal care in a multi-male primate society|url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v425/n6954/abs/nature01866.html|journal=Nature |volume=425 |issue= 6954|pages= 179â181.|doi=10.1038/nature01866|pmid=12968180|access-date=|bibcode=2003Natur.425..179B}}</ref> In one study, researchers analysed the [[DNA]] of 75 juvenile [[baboon]]s to conclude who fathered them. They found that males selectively cared for their own offspring, particularly when their offspring became involved in aggressive confrontations which posed the possibility of injuries or a threat to their [[Social status|social standing]]. Evidently, if males can discriminate between their own offspring and the offspring of others, then there is no purpose in the female attempting to create paternity confusion during the pregnancy stage. This would be counter-intuitive, as, once the offspring is born, the males will know whether the offspring is, or is not, their own. Future research will need to be conducted in this vein to investigate whether males in other species show the ability to discriminate between their own offspring and the offspring of others before coming to any decisive conclusions.
====Concealed estrus as a function of paternity confusion in primates==== Research is fairly consistent in the finding that species with concealed estrus mate at all stages of their ovarian cycle. For instance, mating activity in [[Macaques|assamese macaques]] (''Macaca assamensis'') has been investigated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Furtbauer|first=Ines|date=2011|title=Concealed fertility and extended female sexuality in a non-human primate (macaca assamensis)|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0023105|journal=PLoS ONE |volume=6 |issue= 8|pages= e23105.|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0023105|pmid=21853074|pmc=3154278|access-date=}}</ref> The researchers analysed the levels of [[Menstrual cycle|progesterone]] in the monkeys, in order to establish the ovarian stage of the female, as progesterone peaks following the fertile window. They found that the females concealed estrus and were [[Estrous cycle|sexually receptive]] during the entire mating season. Concealed estrus and sexual receptivity (at all times of the ovarian cycle) aids paternity confusion. This is because the males are unsure of who mated with the female during her fertile period, and so do not know the identity of the father.
Hrdy's hypothesis has been criticised, however, on the basis that some female [[primate]]s show both extended female sexuality and [[sexual swelling|sexual swellings.]]<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> In terms of Hrdy's hypothesis these two concepts are incompatible. Sexual swellings appear only during the most fertile phase of the female's ovarian cycle, with the purpose of advertising fertility. In sharp contrast, according to Hrdy, extended sexuality is adapted to [[Concealed ovulation|conceal fertility]] and ensure mating across all stages of the ovarian cycle, to aid paternity confusion.
===Male-driven hypotheses=== One of the alternative explanations is that extended female sexuality is 'male-driven'. This hypothesis is theoretically based on male uncertainty regarding the fertility status of females.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> Although some [[Menstrual cycle|physiological changes]] occur during the fertile period that may act as reliable indicators (e.g. the concentration of [[Estrogen|oestrogen]] can change female [[Odor|scent]]), most species have not evolved signals advertising fertility (e.g. [[sexual swelling]]s).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pawlowski|first=B|date=1999|title=Loss of oestrus and concealed ovulation in human evolution: the case against the sexual selection hypothesis|url=|journal=Current Anthropology |volume=40 |issue= |pages= 257â275.|doi=10.2307/2991395|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Therefore, males will be unable to detect fertility with any precision. As a result, extended female sexuality is proposed as a male [[Sexual selection|sexually selected]] trait. Males will pursue sexual access throughout the entirety of the [[Menstrual cycle|ovarian cycle]] to increase their chances of [[Fertilisation|impregnating]] the female. According to this hypothesis, females lack any benefit from this activity due to their inability to conceive, yet will be [[Coercion|coerced]] by males to engage in [[sexual intercourse]].<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | last1 = Gangestad | first1 = S. W. | last2 = Thornhill | first2 = R. | year = 1998 | title = Menstrual cycle variation in women's preferences for the scent of symmetrical men | journal = Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences | volume = 265 | issue = 1399| pages = 927â933 | doi=10.1098/rspb.1998.0380 | pmid=9633114 | pmc=1689051}}</ref>
====The training hypothesis====
[[File:HumanSpermVideoAffordableHomeMicroscope.ogv|thumb|The video shows human sperm under a microscope. Author:StirlingJulian]] Another hypothesis claiming that extended female sexuality has evolved to benefit males' interests is the 'training hypothesis'. It has been shown that women's [[immune system]]s attack foreign [[antigen]]s found in [[sperm]].<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> This may reduce the likelihood of conception so reduce the [[reproductive success]] for the males. However, prior exposure to sperm antigens can dampen the immune response to increase the chances of successful conception and [[Implantation (human embryo)|implantation.]]<ref name=":3">{{cite journal | last1 = Robertson | first1 = S. A. | last2 = Bromfield | first2 = J. J. | last3 = Tremellen | first3 = K. P. | year = 2003 | title = Seminal 'priming'for protection from pre-eclampsiaâa unifying hypothesis | url = | journal = Journal of reproductive immunology | volume = 59 | issue = 2| pages = 253â265 | doi=10.1016/s0165-0378(03)00052-4 | pmid=12896827}}</ref> Therefore, males may have evolved to train and 'condition' women's immune systems<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Robertson | first1 = S. A. | year = 2005 | title = Seminal plasma and male factor signalling in the female reproductive tract | url = | journal = Cell and Tissue Research | volume = 322 | issue = 1| pages = 43â52 | doi=10.1007/s00441-005-1127-3}}</ref> by copulating with females during infertile periods, in order to reduce the likelihood of her immune system reacting against the sperm's antigens from lack of exposure. Indeed, research has identified findings consistent with this hypothesis.<ref name=":3" /> Couples who had used condoms before trying to conceive were more likely to suffer complications, such as [[pre-eclampsia]], during pregnancy as a result of the woman's immune system having no prior exposure to the antigens in the sperm. In non-humans, an increased frequency of copulation in crickets has been shown to reduce the female's immune response to sperm.<ref name=":4"/><ref name=":5"/>
This hypothesis has received much criticism. For example, as all mammals experience the same immune system responses to sperm antigens, this hypothesis predicts that all mammals should exhibit extended female sexuality. However, only few species of mammals exhibit sexual behaviour outside the conceptive period.<ref>{{Cite book|title=An Introductiom to Behavioural Endocrinology|last=Nelson|first=R. J.|publisher=Sinauer|year=2000|isbn=|location=Sunderland|pages=}}</ref>
===Spuhler's hypothesis=== Spuhler's hypothesis is a stand-alone hypothesis of extended female sexuality. Spuhler suggests that extended female sexuality has evolved as a by-product of an adaptation in females that increases the levels of [[Adrenal hormone|adrenal]] [[hormone|hormones.]]<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> He proposed that secretion of higher levels of adrenal hormones were initially selected in women in order to increase endurance for walking or running. This hypothesis suggests that the larger [[adrenal gland]]s may have contributed to the development of extended female sexuality as they are also the main source of '[[libido]] hormones', which increase the female's sexual drive.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal | last1 = Gray | first1 = J. P. | last2 = Wolfe | first2 = L. D. | year = 1983 | title = Human female sexual cycles and the concealment of ovulation problem | url = | journal = Journal of Social and Biological Structures | volume = 6 | issue = 4| pages = 345â352 | doi=10.1016/s0140-1750(83)90134-3}}</ref> Thus, extended sexuality is little to do with sexual behavior, or evolutionary advantage, but rather it is just a by-product of hormones.<ref name=":2" /><ref>Williams, G. C. (1966). Adaptation and Natural SelectionPrinceton University Press. ''Princeton, NJ''.</ref> However, this hypothesis cannot account for extended female sexuality in invertebrates, which lack adrenal systems.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" /> Additionally Spuhler highlighted the existence of larger [[thyroid]] and [[adrenal gland]]s in humans compared to other primates. However, no empirical evidence has established the link between hormones and endurance walking as an adaptation and extended female sexuality as a natural incidental effect. As there are costs to extended sexuality, it can be argued that selection would serve the dissociation of extended sexuality from the mechanism that affects endurance walking.<ref name="Thornhill Gangestad" />
==See also== {{colbegin|colwidth=}} * [[Alternative mating strategy]] * [[Animal sexual behaviour]] * [[Human female sexuality]] * [[Human mating strategies]] * [[Strategic pluralism]] * [[Human sexual activity]] * [[Human sexuality]] * [[Major histocompatibility complex and sexual selection]] * [[Mating system]] * [[Ovulatory shift hypothesis]] * [[Reproduction]] {{colend}}

==Further reading== * Buss, D. M. (2015). ''The Handbook of Evolutionary Psychology, Foundation'' (Chapter 13). New York: John Wiley & Sons. * Campbell, L. (2009, June 17). Comparison of the sexuality of humans, common chimpanzees and bonobos. Retrieved from http://darwinstudents.blogspot.co.uk/2009/06/comparison-of-sexuality-of-humans.html * Shackelford, T. K., & Hansen, R. D. (2015). ''The Evolution of Sexuality'' (Chapter 8). New York: Springer. * Simpson, J. A., & Campbell, L. (2013). ''The Oxford Handbook of Close Relationships'' (Chapter 17). Oxford: University Press. * Thornhill, R., & Gangestad, S. W. (2008). ''The Evolutionary Biology of Human Female Sexuality'' (Chapter 3). Oxford: University Press.

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} {{Use British English|date=January 2017}} The '''[[Fisheries Research Services]] (FRS) Marine Laboratory''' is situated in [[Aberdeen]], [[Scotland]]. It was formerly an agency of the [[Scottish Executive Environment and Rural Affairs Department]] and is now part of the Scottish Government.
FRS provides advice to the Scottish Government and [[Politics of the United Kingdom|UK Government]] on fishing and other marine issues.
The FRS Marine Laboratory is a member of the [[Aberdeen Research Consortium]] which also includes:
*[[University of Aberdeen]] *[[Institute of Terrestrial Ecology]], [[Banchory Research Station]] *[[The Macaulay Institute]] *[[Rowett Research Institute]] *[[Robert Gordon University]] *[[Scottish Agricultural College]]
==External links== * [http://www.marlab.ac.uk FRS Marine Laboratory ]

{{Like resume|date=December 2008}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Gavriel Salomon |image = Gabi Salomom picture.JPG |image_size = 150px | birth_date = 12 October 1938 | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|1|4|1938|10|12|df=yes}} | death_place = | nationality = [[Israel]]i | alma_mater = [[Stanford University]] | doctoral_advisor = | known_for = mindful [[transfer of learning]] | influences = | influenced = | | field = [[Educational psychology]] | work_institution = [[University of Haifa]] }} '''Gavriel Salomon''' ([[Hebrew]]: ×××¨××× ×¡×××××, 1938 - 2016)<ref>http://apadiv15.org/2016/04/13/in-memoriam-gavriel-salomon/</ref> was an [[Israel]]i [[educational psychology|educational psychologist]] who conducted research on [[cognition]] and instruction, in particular the cognitive effects of media's symbol systems, [[transfer of learning]], and the design of cognitive tools and technology-afforded learning environments. He was a Professor Emeritus in the department of education at the [[University of Haifa]].
== Work == He served as the Editor in Chief of the ''[[Educational Psychologist (academic journal)|Educational Psychologist]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Salomon |first=Gavriel |date=1992 |title=Editor's Comment |url= |journal=[[Educational Psychologist (academic journal)|Educational Psychologist]] |publisher= |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages= 1|doi=10.1207/s15326985ep2701_1}}</ref>
==Awards and honours==
* In 1993â1994, Salomon occupied the [[Cleveringa]] Chair at [[Leiden University]], [[The Netherlands]]. * In 2001, he received the [[Israel Prize]], for education.<ref>{{Cite web| title = Israel Prize Official Site (in Hebrew) â Recipientâs C.V. | url = http://cms.education.gov.il/EducationCMS/Units/PrasIsrael/Tashsa/GavrielSalomon/KorotHaimGavrielSalomon.htm}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| title = Israel Prize Official Site (in Hebrew) â Judges' Rationale for Grant to Recipient | url = http://cms.education.gov.il/EducationCMS/Units/PrasIsrael/Tashsa/GavrielSalomon/NimokyHsoftim.htm}}</ref> * He also received the [[Sylvia Scribner]] Award from the [[American Educational Research Association]].<ref>Israeli appointed to European Community panel. Jerusalem Post, 2002, February 10, page 3.</ref> * In 2006, Salomon was elected as fellow of the International Academy of Education. * In 2011, Prof. Salomon also received [[:de:Peter-Becker-Preis|"Peter-Becker-Preis fÃ¼r Friedens- und Konfliktforschung"]], which is the highest award for Peace and Conflict Studies in Germany, perhaps in the whole world.
==See also== *[[List of Israel Prize recipients]]

'''Gender history''' is a sub-field of [[history]] and [[gender studies]], which looks at the past from the perspective of [[gender]]. It is in many ways, an outgrowth of [[women's history]]. The discipline considers in what ways historical events and periodization impact women differently from men. For instance, in an influential article in 1977, "Did Women have a Renaissance?", [[Joan Kelly]] questioned whether the notion of a Renaissance was relevant to women.<ref name = "kelly">"Did Women have a Renaissance?" ''Becoming Visible: Women in European History''. Houghton Mifflin, 1977.</ref> Gender historians are also interested in how gender difference has been perceived and configured at different times and places, usually with the assumption that such differences are socially constructed. These social constructions of gender throughout time are also represented as changes in the expected norms of behavior for those labeled male or female. Those who study gender history note these changes in norms and those performing them over time and interpret what those changes say about the larger social/cultural/political climate.
==Impact== Despite its relatively short life, gender history (and its forerunner women's history) has had a rather significant effect on the general study of [[history]]. Since the 1960s, when the initially small field first achieved a measure of acceptance, it has gone through a number of different phases, each with its own challenges and outcomes, but always making an impact of some kind on the historical discipline. Although some of the changes to the study of history have been quite obvious, such as increased numbers of books on famous women or simply the admission of greater numbers of women into the historical profession, other influences are more subtle, even though they may be more politically groundbreaking in the end. By 1970, gender historians turned to documenting ordinary women's expectations, aspirations and status. In the 80s with the rise of the feminist movement, the focus shifted to uncovering women' oppression and discrimination. Nowadays, gender history is more about charting female agency and recognizing female achievements in several fields that were usually dominated by men.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.history.ac.uk/ihr/Focus/Gender/articles.html|title=History in Focus: articles on gender history|website=www.history.ac.uk|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref>
===Within the profession=== According to historian [[Joan Wallach Scott|Joan Scott]], conflict occurred between Women's History [[List of historians|historians]] and other historians in a number of ways.<ref name = "scott">"Gender: A Useful Category of Historical Analysis," [[American Historical Review]] 91, No. 5 (December 1986).</ref> In the [[American Historical Association]], when [[feminism|feminists]] argued that female historians were treated unequally within the field and underrepresented in the association, they were essentially leveling charges of historical negligence by traditional historians. Notions of [[professional]]ism were not rejected outright, but they were accused of being biased.
===Supplementary history=== According to Scott, the construction of Women's History as "supplementary" to the rest of history had a similar effect. At first glance, a supplement simply adds information which has been missing from the greater story, but as Scott points out, it also questions why the information was left out in the first place. Whenever it is noticed that a woman found to be missing from [[recorded history|written history]], Women's History first describes her role, second, examines which mechanisms allowed her role to be omitted, and third, asks to what other information these mechanisms were blind.
===Gender theory=== Finally, the advent of [[gender studies|gender theory]] once again challenged commonly held ideas of the discipline, including those scholars studying Women's History. [[Postmodernism|Post-modern]] criticism of essentialising [[social construction|socially constructed]] groups, be they [[gender]] groups or otherwise, pointed out the weaknesses in various sorts of history. In the past, [[historian]]s have attempted to describe the shared experience of large numbers of people, as though these people and their experiences were homogeneous and uniform. Women have multiple identities, influenced by any number of factors including [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]] and [[Social class|class]], and any examination of history which conflates their experiences, fails to provide an accurate picture.
==History of Masculinity== The history of masculinity emerged as a specialty in the 1990s, evidenced by numerous studies of men in groups, and how concepts of masculinity shape their values and behavior. Gail Bederman identified two approaches: one that emerged from women's history and one that ignored it: :Two types of âmenâs historyâ are being written these days. One builds on twenty years of womenâs history scholarship, analyzing masculinity as part of larger gender and cultural processes. The other . . . looks to the past to see how men in early generations understood (and misunderstood) themselves as men. Books of the second type mostly ignore womenâs history findings and methodology.<ref>Gail Bederman, ''Journal of American History'' 84 (1997) p. 680</ref>
== Gender in religion == All over the world, religion is formed around a divine, supernatural figure. While the idea of the divine, supernatural figure varies from religion to religion, each one is framed around different concepts of what it means to be male and female. Furthermore, the religion of a culture usually directly corresponds or is influenced by the culture's gender structure, like the family structures and/or the state. Therefore the religious structure and the gender structure work together to form and define a culture, creating the defining structures of equality and uniformity.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Gender in History: Global Perspectives|last=Wiesner-Hanks|first=Merry E|publisher=Blackwell Publishing|year=2011|isbn=978-1-4051-8995-8|location=Malden, MA|pages=109,110}}</ref>
